bestBHT.bht: The disciples were astonished to hear that it is difficult for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God, as they were still focused on their temporal views of the kingdom. This should be a cause for concern, as riches can hinder our entrance into God's kingdom. However, despite their astonishment, the disciples did not shy away from the teachings of Christ. We ought to tremble at the warnings of God, not discouraged, but rather awakened to the seriousness of the matter. It is worth considering that if rich men, with all their advantages, struggle to enter the kingdom, how much more difficult must it be for those who are poor.

Henry Alford: Who, not What rich man, which would have been a far shallower and narrower enquiry, but a general question—what man?
Since all are striving to be rich
The disciples yet looked for a temporal Kingdom, and therefore would naturally be dismayed at hearing that it was so difficult for any rich man to enter it.
John Calvin: It ought to awaken in us no little anxiety, that riches obstruct the entrance into the kingdom of God; for, wherever we turn our eyes, a thousand obstacles will present themselves.
While they were struck with astonishment, they did not shrink from the doctrines of Christ.
Thus it will be of service to us to tremble at the threatenings of God: whenever he denounces anything that is gloomy or dreadful, provided that our minds are not discouraged, but rather aroused.
Philip Schaff: Since all may have some possessions, and naturally love to have more.
Their temporal views of the kingdom were also mixed with their question.
Archibald T. Robertson: Were astonished (εξεπλησσοντο). Imperfect descriptive of their blank amazement. They were literally "struck out."
John Gill: They were, as Mark says, 'astonished out of measure': they did not imagine there was any difficulty of rich men coming into the kingdom of the Messiah."

though he meant by the kingdom of heaven a spiritual kingdom, a Gospel church state here, or the heavenly glory, or both; but when he expressed, by the proverb, the impracticableness of such men becoming the subjects thereof, their amazement increased.

they might reason with themselves, that if rich men did not come into the kingdom of the Messiah, they would oppose him and his kingdom, with all their force and strength; and then what would become of such poor men as themselves.
John Wesley: Who then can be saved? — If rich men, with all their advantages, cannot? Who?"
A poor man; a peasant; a beggar: ten thousand of them, sooner than one that is rich.

bhtAttempts.bht: The disciples were astonished to hear that it is difficult for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God, as they were still focused on their temporal views of the kingdom. This should be a cause for concern, as riches can hinder our entrance into God's kingdom. However, despite their astonishment, the disciples did not shy away from the teachings of Christ. We ought to tremble at the warnings of God, not discouraged, but rather awakened to the seriousness of the matter. It is worth considering that if rich men, with all their advantages, struggle to enter the kingdom, how much more difficult must it be for those who are poor.

The disciples' astonishment at learning that it is difficult for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God reveals their temporal understanding of the kingdom. This realization should cause us concern, as riches can hinder our entrance into God's kingdom. However, the disciples did not shy away from Christ's teachings despite their amazement. We should tremble at God's warnings, not discouraged but awakened to the gravity of the situation. If even the rich struggle to enter the kingdom, how much more challenging must it be for the poor?

The disciples' astonishment at hearing that it is difficult for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God stemmed from their temporal view of the kingdom as a physical one. This should concern us, as wealth can hinder our entrance into God's kingdom. Despite their amazement, the disciples did not shy away from Christ's teachings. We ought to tremble at God's warnings, not discouraged but awakened to the seriousness of the matter. If even the rich struggle to enter the kingdom, how much more difficult must it be for the poor?

The disciples' astonishment at the difficulty for a rich man to enter the kingdom of God stemmed from their temporal kingdom expectations. This should concern us, as wealth becomes an obstacle to entering God's kingdom. However, the disciples did not shy away from Christ's teachings despite their surprise. We should heed God's warnings, not be discouraged, but rather awakened by them. If even the rich find it challenging to enter the kingdom, how much harder must it be for the poor?

The disciples' astonishment at the difficulty faced by a rich man to enter the kingdom of God reveals their temporal view of the kingdom. Wealth can hinder our entrance into God's kingdom, which should be a cause for concern. However, the disciples did not shy away from Christ's teachings despite their amazement. We should tremble at God's warnings, remaining unshaken, but rather awakened to their gravity. If the rich struggle to enter the kingdom, the plight for the poor must be even more challenging.
